narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Have a deeper understanding of human rights and related policies

I developed studying skills and synthesizing skills. The matters discussed are not controversial enough to create a deep debate, but help the creation of a framework to adres many world wide issues. It helped me grow a greater understanding of human rights and the purpose of their enforcement.

Critical thinking and analyzing, to appreciate and understand different points of views. I alao learned a lot of many countries in the world, I know and understand the human rights very well, I know about the UPR in many countries, I learned about human rights watch and other non-profit organizations. I learned so much from this class, specially to be empathic.

I have always been fascinated by politics and human rights and yet as a high school student I never had the chance to study human rights or politics systematically. This course was definitely the key led me to the field of political science. I was able to evaluate human rights base on the international laws and treaties. In addition, I always learnt the historical development of human rights and also the meaning of some philosophical terms such as human dignity. Before this course, human rights to me were only an abstract concept. Now however, I start to see it was one of the most important obligations the politicians need to meet. And with the knowledges I learnt from the class, I shall aim one day, to be able to assist the development of human rights performance on a global scale.

This course taught how to analyze the legal framework for human rights globally. I learned about the human rights based approach, I learned the true meaning of public policy, moreover, I've learned the core principles of human rights.
I developed my knowledge about international bodies and how the international framework and domestic governance interact to guarantee human rights.

I really learned how to evaluate issue using the human rights approach. I also got to learn so much official declarations that lays the foundation for all human rights issues. Arm with these knowledge mostly learn in the first three weeks, I got to evaluate the UPR of my own country and present it to the class, which is a really valuable experience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The trip to Human Right Watch is quite impressive. The presentation on UPR in respective countries of students in class help them learn more about the Human Right situation in their own country and worldwide.

Strengths:
-Very intuitive
-good reading material
- the professor has very deep knowledge on the topics discussed

Weaknesses:
-Hard to understand the assignments and their purpose
There is so much information just to fit in 5 weeks, but overall, the course was amazing

The course was very insightful, it helps those who have never touched on the area of human rights end up, feeling they are ready to become a human right defender. During the process of preparing for presentation and my final policy memo, I felt I have learnt more that what I delivered. 
The knowledge we learnt in the class can perhaps be, more detailed. The amount of information was so immense that it was hard for the students to dig further into each areas of learning. 
Also more class discussion would be great.

I am satisfied with how the course was taught. The visit at Human Rights Watch was really meaningful. The professor encouraged the students to engage into civil debates with the aim of observing how people from different parts of the world interpret human rights. The UPR presentations were really useful.

The strength of the class is that it consists of several guest visits and one fruitful field trip, which helped me to understand the real implementation of HR. The weakness is that the actual class agenda is inconsistent with the syllabus, so the preview is sometimes confusing.

The strength are included in what I learned. Another strength I want to include is the various backgrounds of each students and how that contribute to class discussions. 
The class can possibly be improved if reading questions are provided in the beginning. These can be not for answering but for guiding us through the reading because it is hard to process when we were first reading it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are interested in human rights and international law.
Yes with the condition that person has a previous knowledge on the issue of human rights and is clearly interested on how human rights work and developed.

Yes. Completely. Because this course opened my mind to so many things I didnt know about. It made me less ignorant in so many aspects. Actually this class motivated me to help refugees in Mexio and I am now a volunteer in a refugee shelter. I learned to be more empathic.

Yes definitely, especially those who are passionate about humanity. This is both a Political and philosophical course that made me question both the flaws and beauties of our society. It was insightful and the amount of information I gained was immense.

If you are interested in Human Rights and international politics, just like the name of the class says, then this course is ideal. However, I would warn the student that the workload of this course is manageable but requires dedication. Reading makes up half of the course's work.

Yes, I would for sure recommend it to other students interested in human rights. 
The value of this class is not only from how our professor teaches and provides us with ample materials but also from how students interpret materials from different perspectives. It's a really valuable experience.
